briefOverview: Adam and Eve learn the meaning of sacrifice and the gospel of redemption, while apostasy spreads through Cain’s rebellion and the rise of secret oaths. The chapter traces early civilization, judgment on murderers, and God’s ongoing call to repentance through revealed ordinances.
summary: After being driven from Eden, Adam and Eve labor, offer firstlings as commanded, and learn from an angel that sacrifice is a similitude of the Only Begotten; the Holy Ghost bears record, and they rejoice that through their mortal experience they can have joy and see God again. They teach their children, but Satan persuades many to reject God. Cain rejects God’s counsel, makes a secret oath with Satan to murder for gain, and kills Abel; God confronts and curses him, sets a protective mark, and Cain departs to the land of Nod. Cain’s descendants develop city life, herding, music, and metalwork, while violence intensifies, especially under Lamech, who enters the same murderous oath and kills to protect the secret. Secret combinations spread, leading to widespread wickedness and a sore curse upon the earth. Despite this, God continues to call all to repent and to believe in the Only Begotten, declaring that the gospel, confirmed to Adam by holy ordinance, would remain in the world to the end.
externalContext: The Book of Moses is part of the Pearl of Great Price in the Latter-day Saint tradition, deriving from Joseph Smith’s early 1830s revision of Genesis and expanding the primeval history with explicit Christological interpretation. Its Cain and Lamech material parallels Genesis 4 but adds covenantal oaths with Satan and an emphasis on revealed ordinances from the beginning. References to firstling offerings align with ancient Near Eastern sacrificial practice, where the firstborn of the flock signified dedication to deity. The motif of secret oaths resonates with ancient covenant-making rituals, though the framing of “secret combinations” is distinctive in Latter-day Saint scripture. The phrase “meridian of time” reflects an LDS usage that situates Christ’s mortal ministry as the pivotal midpoint of human history.
externalReferences: This chapter closely parallels Genesis 4:1–24, including the offerings of Cain and Abel, the divine warning about sin (Genesis 4:7), the mark and sevenfold vengeance (Genesis 4:15), and Lamech’s saying (Genesis 4:23–24), and echoes the toil motif of Genesis 3:19. Abel’s acceptable offering and Cain’s wickedness are treated in Hebrews 11:4 and 1 John 3:12; the contrast between Abel’s blood and Christ’s is noted in Hebrews 12:24. The identification of sacrifice as typifying the Only Begotten accords with John 1:14, 17 and the atonement theology developed in Hebrews 9–10 and Revelation 13:8. The motif of “secret combinations” is further elaborated in Latter-day Saint scripture, notably Ether 8:18–26 and Helaman 6:21–30.

sectionTitles.title: Cainite Line, Secret Oaths, Enduring Gospel

practicalQuestions: When God’s reasons are not yet clear, how can I obey in faith as Adam did with sacrifice?
How do envy and anger show up in my life, and what safeguards keep them from becoming harm to others?
What practices help my family remember and teach God’s commandments across generations?
Where might secrecy and exploitative gain be distorting my commitments, and how can I bring them into the light?
How do I respond when corrected by God’s word—defensively like Cain or repentantly as invited here?
uncertainAreas: The phrase “thou shalt rule over him” in verse 23 is ambiguous (who is ruling over whom). The statement that Cain was “also before the world” and being called “Perdition” is theologically distinctive and open to interpretive debate. The nature of the “mark of Cain” is unspecified. The meaning and origin of the title “Master Mahan” and the mechanics of the secret oaths are not fully explained in the text.
